Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Reputation-Escalation-as-a-Service: Analyses and Defenses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Living in an age when services are often rated, people are increasingly depending on reputation of sellers or products/apps when making purchases online. This puts pressure on people to gain and maintain a high reputation by offering reliable and high-quality services and/or products, which benefits the society at large. Unfortunately, due to extremely high competition in e-commerce or app stores, recently reputation manipulation related services have quickly developed into a sizable business, which is termed Reputation-Escalation-as-a-Service (REaaS). As REaaS attacks grow in scale, effective countermeasures must be designed to detect and defend against them.

This research addresses REaaS from two aspects. First, it aims to understand the economics of REaaS by conducting empirical studies of e-markets. Second, it aims to develop defensive measures, which involve both technical approaches and market intervention. The technical approaches focus on detection of REaaS from e-markets, and novel detection techniques will be developed using content analysis, machine learning, social ties, and graph theory. For market invention, after a holistic analysis of REaaS, this research aims to identify its bottleneck (the weakest link) and also measure the efficacy of intervention. The outcome of this data-driven security research will enhance security education with labs based on social-economic data analysis. The success of this research will attract more attention of industry practitioners, government sectors, and academia to jointly tackle the REaaS problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has two main goals: (1) to understand the economics of Reputation Escalation as a Service (REaaS) by an empirical study of mobile apps' metadata such as reviews/ratings; (2) to develop technical approaches for detecting REaaS for mobile apps based on the previously learned REaaS behaviors.

To achieve the first goal, we have tracked and collected multiple datasets.  For example, we built a large dataset for 16,000 IoS apps (70,000 versions) with 19 millions reviews for  the period of 11 months in 2017. The uniqueness of this dataset is that it contains very detailed metadata information for each app: daily ranking, change of ranking, download numbers, when/whether it is removed from market, deleted reviews. This dataset helped us get much deeper insight on the manipulation behavior and identified effective features for detecting app ranking/review manipulation as well as fake review providers.   

To achieve the second goal, we developed multiple effective and efficient techniques. For example, based on graph theory, we built bipartite graphs consisting of apps and reviewers, and proposed efficient heuristic algorithms to detect promoted apps and their attackers. We also proposed several machine learning techniques to detect individually promoted apps and identify the most significant features for determining promoted apps in different app stores.  Novel methods have also been designed to assess the quality of an app based on its in-born (code-level) features instead of its user-generated information (e.g., number of downloads, reviews and ratings). The mismatching between the quality of an app and its actual ranking may indicate manipulation attacks.

The promposed techniques have been thoroughly evaluated on downloaded datasets as well as in the actual app stores at the real time. For example, we ran one of our algorithms against Apple App Store of China. In 33 hours, the algorithm examined at realtime 2,188 apps with 4,841,720 reviews and 1,622,552 reviewers. It reported 108 abused apps, among which 104 apps were finally confirmed to be abused. On the other hand, with over 50 features, our machine learning approach got very high detection rate (over 95%). 

The technical outcome of our project has been broadly disseminated through multiple publications in major security conferences and journals, as well as in over ten seminar talks in both US and intenational schools. It has helped in training the research skills of two PhD students and three master students with multiple theses.
